Hi Delhia, and thanks so much for having me! Like many romance writers, Iâ€™m a huge Jane Austen fangirl. So, to help you celebrate the 5 year anniversary of Between Dreams and Reality, I thought Iâ€™d share ten quotes containing Janeâ€™s timeless wisdom and reveal why her advice still applies in the iPhone ageâ€”a mere 200 years after Pride and Prejudice was first published.

Jane on love (and understanding men):

â€œTo be fond of dancing was a certain step towards falling in love.â€ â€•Pride and Prejudice

It doesnâ€™t matter if theyâ€™re playing Beethoven in the ballroom or Kesha in the club. If youâ€™re going to dance, you need to let go of those inhibitions and (as my dance teacher used to shout at me) â€œshake what your mama gave you.â€ This is a certain step toward gaining a gentlemanâ€™s attention, which could very well lead to capturing his affections. Or getting free drinks.

â€œIf I loved you less, I might be able to talk about it more.â€ â€•Emma

Weâ€™ve all been there. The more we care about someone or something, the harder it is to discuss. So if your boyfriend/husband clamps up, caveman-style, you might want to cut him some slackâ€”especially if heâ€™s as hot as Mr. Knightley!

â€œOne half of the world cannot understand the pleasures of the other.â€ â€•Emma

The Authoress was way ahead of the Men are from Mars, Women are from Venus movement of the 90â€™s. And I think she said it much more eloquently.

â€œI always deserve the best treatment because I never put up with any other.â€ â€•Emma

You go, Jane! I believe the Queen of Soul wrote a song expressing this very sentiment, which Kelly Clarkson echoed. (Coincidentally, Miss Clarkson bought a ring that once belonged to Janeâ€¦and then had to give it back!)

â€œPerhaps it is our imperfections that make us so perfect for one another!â€ â€•Emma

When it comes to love, we donâ€™t need a guy to be perfectâ€¦as long as heâ€™s perfect for us. Itâ€™s all about compromise. As in, I can handle a little snoring if he can deal with my beauty products cluttering up the bathroom counter.

Jane on friendship:

â€œThere is nothing I would not do for those who are really my friends. I have no notion of loving people by halves, it is not my nature.â€ â€•Northanger Abbey

We should all be blessed with friends like thisâ€”friends who are with us through thick and thin. They stand by you through bad breakups, bad haircuts, and more.

Jane on the secrets to happiness:

â€œI wish, as well as everybody else, to be perfectly happy; but, like everybody else, it must be in my own way.â€ â€•Sense and Sensibility

Thereâ€™s no one prescribed path to happiness. Weâ€™re all trying to find our way, find the road thatâ€™s right for us. So we need to be kind to one another!

â€œWe have all a better guide in ourselves, if we would attend to it, than any other person can be.â€ â€•Mansfield Park

Itâ€™s easy to get a caught up in the social media frenzy. And itâ€™s fun! There are countless opinions whirling around us in a virtual tornado of tweets, posts, and pins. To avoid being swept away by it all, we occasionally need to unplug and listen to the quiet voice inside us. (And not just the one saying, More chocolate. Now.)

â€œThere is nothing like staying at home for real comfort.â€â€•Emma

This is so trueâ€”largely because of my momâ€™s eggplant parm and meatballs. But also because home is where people know and love us. Itâ€™s where we can be ourselves. And no one knows us better than family and friends.

Jane on success:

â€œIt isnâ€™t what we say or think that defines us, but what we do.â€ â€•Sense and Sensibility

Thereâ€™s certainly nothing wrong with thoughtful discourse and pleasant conversation, but we canâ€™t sit around the drawing room having tea all day long. We hear you, Jane! We need to get out there and make a difference in little ways and big ways. Less talk. More action.

And thatâ€™s my cue to wrap up this post! Hereâ€™s my question for you: Do you have a favorite Jane Austen quote? How does it hold up in 2016? Thank you! And happy anniversary, Delhia!

I donâ€™t think I take more than a few steps when something crunches beneath the sole of my left boot. I think itâ€™s a stick, but the sound seems off, especially since the forest floor is so moist. I lift my foot only to jump away.

â€œTaran, are you coming?â€ Shayna calls when I donâ€™t move.

â€œTaran?â€ she asks again.

I swallow hard, hoping Iâ€™m imagining things as they run back to me.

â€œWhatâ€™s wrong?â€ Emme asks. Unlike Shayna whoâ€™s fired up for all the action about to go down, I can sense the worry in her voice.

â€œBren . . .â€ I begin, pointing to the spot near my feet. â€œIs that a, um, toe?â€

He cocks his head. â€œNah.â€

Emme places her hand over her heart and sighs. â€œOh, goodâ€”â€

â€œItâ€™s a thumb,â€ he answers. He sniffs the air. â€œRight hand, male, and the poor bastardâ€™s been dead a long time.â€ He looks ahead. â€œYeah, this shitâ€™s not good. Call it in, Shayna, but type it. Donâ€™t use voice-to text.â€

â€œWhy, dude?â€ Shayna asks, reaching for her phone in her back pocket.

â€œBecause Iâ€™m not sure how well this bitch can hear, or if she has other things listening for her,â€ he responds.

He motions ahead to a crow. It squawks twice in our direction and flutters away.

Shayna lifts her phone to show us the blank screen. â€œPhoneâ€™s dead, kids.â€ She quickly pockets it and places a handful of toothpicks in her palm. â€œI wouldnâ€™t bother, Emme,â€ she adds when Emme reaches for her phone. I doubt any of our phones are working.â€

â€œSheâ€™s right,â€ Bren says. He shoves his phone into the backpack Emme is carrying and peels off his white T-shirt.

â€œThis keeps getting better and better,â€ I mutter.

Bren strips out of his jeans, leaving only his underwear and shit-kickers on. â€œEm, stay behind me,â€ he tells her. â€œShayna, youâ€™ve the rear.â€

Which leaves me in front of Shayna and the most protected. Iâ€™ll be honest, this helpless damsel in distress role does nothing for my morale.

I march ahead, forcing myself to snap out of the shock of finding some guyâ€™s thumb, push aside my fear, and tap into my inner diva. I remember a little too late that my inner diva is louder and usually sashays in platform stilettos. I slow my steps, careful not to disturb the creepy things hiding in the bushes.

Let me be the first to tell you, woods are bullshit and top of the scales of the scary meter, second only to graveyards. Itâ€™s the reason so many horror movies are based here, and why Iâ€™m watching out for psychos with machetes lurking behind trees. But given our past experiences, where danger lurks, so do the dark ones. Iâ€™ve had my fill of forests, alleyways, construction sites, but especially these damn eerie woods!

With every step, the canopy of twisting branches above us tightens, darkening the forest. But itâ€™s the shift in the air that sends goosebumps skittering up my arms. Instead of warmth, the surrounding breeze grows dank and heavy. My stare darts in every direction, knowing weâ€™re no longer alone.

Something shoots out from beneath an old log, scuttling like a crab and moving so fast I barely catch sight of it. It skitters beneath a spread of thick ferns, causing the cluster of leaves to tremble as it passes, only to come to an abrupt stop.

Okay. So much for not disturbing the creepy.
